I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  regional  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  consistent  with  the 
South Asia regional cooperation strategy, 2011–2015, which places high priority on regional 
connectivity and trade facilitation projects.1 The TA was conceptualized following consultations 
conducted for the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) trade facilitation 
during October  2012–March  2013.  It  was  included  in the  South  Asia regional  cooperation 
operations business plan, 2013-2015.2 
  
2.  At the meetings of the SASEC trade facilitation and transport working group (TFTWG) in 
2010–2012, the governments of SASEC countries3 requested continued support from the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  on  SASEC  trade  facilitation.  ADB  approved  in  November  2012 
SASEC Trade Facilitation Program loans and grants to Bangladesh, Bhutan, and Nepal to help 
develop modern customs administrations, streamline regulations and procedures, and provide 
improved services and information to traders.4 In addition, at the SASEC TFTWG meeting held 
in Thimphu, Bhutan, in November 2012, SASEC country delegations (i) agreed to expand 
assistance to trade facilitation further through additional TA to ensure full support for ongoing 
initiatives and (ii) requested ADB to explore the possibility of providing TA to respond to the 
specific trade facilitation needs of SASEC countries.  
 
3.  The inception meeting of the SASEC customs subgroup, which was held on 28 March 
2013, broadly agreed on a work plan of priority issues and activities and on the expected impact 
and outcome of the TA, supporting its design and implementation. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.5  
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  South Asia is among the least economically integrated regions in the world. In 2011, only 
5% of South Asia’s trade is intraregional, compared with over 26% in Southeast Asia and 54% 
in East Asia. Despite progress made since 2005 in facilitating inland and cross-border trade—
shortening the time it takes on average for exports to clear customs from 35 days in 2007 to 
less than 33 days in 2011—trade impediments remain. They include the (i) large number of 
documents required for border clearance, (ii) lack of streamlined customs and other border 
procedures,  and  (iii)  lack  of  efficient  and  modern  customs  facilities.  Consequently,  border 
crossings in South Asia are among the most congested in the world. It takes 32.4 days to export 
from South Asia, compared with 23.1 days from East Asia and the Pacific.6 These issues are 
shared to varying degrees by all four SASEC countries. As such, a subregional approach of 
sharing experiences and technical cooperation among them is an effective way to address 
these issues. 
 
5.  Limited  customs  cooperation.  SASEC  customs  cooperation  has  been  subsumed 
under a broader committee—the TFTWG—and has been addressing general aspects of trade 
facilitation. One result, however, has been a lack of focus on regional policy coordination on

specific customs matters such as customs management and administration procedures. Many 
impediments remain, such as  
(i)  processes across countries that are not harmonized,  
(ii)  excessive inspection at borders,  
(iii)  multiple transshipments due to limited or lacking transit rights, and  
(iv)  uncertain and expensive cargo clearance.  
 
6.  Weak  capacity  to  comply  with  international  best  practices.  Trade  facilitation 
measures  are  numerous. They  have  become  increasingly  more  complex  and  technical  as 
computers and information and communication technology (ICT) have proliferated in customs 
reform and modernization, signaling a permanent shift in global customs management. In this 
context, the introduction of international customs best practices is relatively new in South Asia. 
Awareness and appreciation of such practices are in their infancy. The situation is compounded 
by a shortage of skills necessary to modernize customs procedures.  
 
7.  Different  degrees  of  customs  automation.  Most  South  Asian  countries  have 
automated customs systems, but they are limited to different degrees. As countries prepare to 
comply  with  international  standards  and  to  implement  ICT  solutions,  they  can  proceed  at 
different speeds and in different sequence, adopt different platforms and standards, and vary in 
the extent of sector coverage. While trade flow can improve within borders, regional trade can 
be facilitated optimally only if national customs administration systems are able to communicate 
efficiently.  Other  important  issues  pertain  to  legal  jurisdiction,  national  and  regional  policy 
sequencing, and different kinds of ICT infrastructure and degrees of preparedness to automate 
customs.  
 
8.   The TA will address these issues by supporting the implementation of trade facilitation 
in Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, the Maldives, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. The Maldives and Sri Lanka, 
which are not SASEC countries, will participate in knowledge-sharing activities, as their trade-
facilitation problems are similar to those of SASEC countries. Their participation aligns with the 
regional cooperation strategy for South Asia, which covers not only the SASEC program, but 
other regional cooperation programs involving all South Asian countries (footnote 1).  
 
9.  The TA will build on an ongoing subproject that is building capacity for SASEC trade 
facilitation  with  funding  from  the  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development.7 It  will 
complement  the  planned  TA  projects  in  Bangladesh,  Bhutan,  and  Nepal,  supporting  their 
participation in SASEC trade facilitation, and helping implement the SASEC Trade Facilitation 
Program loans and grants (footnote 4). 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be more efficient, transparent, secure, and service-oriented 
processing of cross-border trade in South Asia. Progress will be indicated by (i) shorter average 
times required for export and import and (ii) the percentage of shipments “green channeled,” or 
not physically inspected in Bangladesh, Bhutan, and Nepal. The outcome will be modern and 
effective customs administration and management in participating countries.  
                                                
7  ADB. 2006. Establishing the Australia—ADB South Asia Development Partnership Facility. Manila. The Subproject 
(SASEC Transport and Trade Facilitation Capacity Building and Institutional Strengthening), with a budget of 
$1,175,000, will support program implementation in key areas.

3 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have two outputs: (i) enhanced cooperation between and among customs 
agencies in South Asia and (ii) an interface framework for customs administration systems in 
SASEC countries.  
12.  Enhanced cooperation between and among customs agencies in South Asia. The 
SASEC TFTWG has emphasized the importance of cooperation among customs agencies in 
the four SASEC countries as part of efforts to facilitate trade in the subregion. A customs 
subgroup of the SASEC TFTWG was established in March 2013 to serve as a platform for 
increased  cooperation.  The  TA  will  support  meetings  of  the  customs  subgroup  and  the 
participation of customs officials in SASEC countries and international experts who will serve as 
resource persons helping to prepare and facilitate the meetings. The meetings of the customs 
subgroup  will  serve  as  venues  at  which  SASEC  countries  share  their  experiences  of 
implementing customs reform and modernization as promoted under SASEC and explore ways 
to harmonize and streamline customs information and processes to facilitate trade within the 
subregion. The TA may also support analytical studies on priority customs issues in SASEC, 
which will be agreed by the customs subgroup. 
13.  The TA will assist in conducting subregional workshops and seminars at which South 
Asian  countries  can  exchange  experiences  and  share  information  on  international  good 
practices in implementing priority  customs reform measures in line with the revised Kyoto 
Convention, the so-called SAFE framework of standards to secure and facilitate global trade, 
and the application of ICT in customs. ADB will forge a partnership with the World Customs 
Organization (WCO) Asia Pacific Regional Office for Capacity Building and with the Customs 
and  Tariff  Bureau  of  Japan’s  Ministry  of  Finance  toward  organizing  and  conducting  these 
workshops and seminars. 
 
14.  Interface framework for customs administration systems in SASEC countries. As a 
pilot initiative of customs cooperation, the TA will help develop an interface framework for 
customs  administration  systems  between  and  among  SASEC  countries.  The  four  SASEC 
countries  are  investing  in  automated  customs  management  and  administration  systems  to 
promote streamlined and transparent trade processes and procedures. They have, to varying 
degrees, expressed interest in establishing national single windows. As a first step, the TA will 
support  studies  and  consultations  to  (i)  identify  the  benefits  of  promoting  the  interface  of 
customs  administration  systems  and  inform  the  countries  about  them;  (ii)  determine  the 
associated issues and challenges to be addressed; and (iii) formulate a strategy and road map 
for a feasible process of creating a better customs administration interface, which will be tackled 
as  part  of  the  SASEC  customs  subgroup  agenda.  International  customs  administration 
specialists will be engaged to help develop this framework. The Customs and Tariff Bureau of 
Japan and the WCO Asia Pacific Regional Office for Capacity Building will be consulted in the 
preparation of the framework. 
 
15.  The potential risks to attaining the TA’s expected impact, outcome, and outputs arise 
from political instability and exogenous economic shocks that might affect the subregion, the 
lack of capacity  in border agencies to implement trade facilitation reform, and the lack of 
commitment on the part of SASEC customs agencies to ensure the active and continuing 
participation of senior officials in all the activities of the SASEC customs subgroup.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million and will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from August 2013 to July 2015. The ADB 
South Asia Department (SARD) will be the executing agency. ADB will work with the WCO in 
implementing the TA.8 Building on a training needs assessment workshop held on 28 March 
2013 in Bangkok, tentative training programs have also been identified for 2013 on authorized 
economic  operators,  a  WCO  compendium  on  a  national  single  window  for  South  Asian 
countries, valuation, and time release studies.  
 
18.  WCO  officials  will  share  their  semiannual  capacity-building  programs  with  SARD 
regularly to better synchronize the training programs of both institutions in the future. SARD will 
coordinate and regularly share information with the Customs and Tariff Bureau of the Ministry of 
Finance of Japan.  
 
19.  The TA will require (i) trade facilitation specialists (international, 30 person-months); 
(ii) resource  persons  (international,  3.5  person-months),  who  will  build  capacity  to  discuss 
international good practices and provide advice on specific TA outputs; and (iii) trade facilitation 
coordinating analysts (national, 34 person-months). 
 
20.  Individual  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  line  with  their  specific  expertise  and  the 
diversity of tasks to be undertaken, under the active management of SARD staff. Consultants 
will be engaged as individuals in accordance with ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants are in 
Appendix 3. 
 
21.  Workshops, trainings, and seminars will be held during implementation. All procurement 
of goods and other services under the TA will accord with ADB Procurement Guidelines (2013, 
as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will accord with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
22.   The TA will be monitored principally through meetings of the SASEC TFTWG, the 
SASEC customs subgroup, and national and regional meetings to be held under the auspices of 
the TA. TA outputs will be evaluated by SARD through the annual TA implementation review 
mission with the assistance of the ADB resident missions.  
 
23.   Good practices and lessons from the TA will be (i) documented in the progress reports 
submitted to SASEC TFTWG and posted in the SASEC website (www.sasec.asia) and (ii) 
reported  during  meetings  of  the  ADB’s  regional  cooperation  and  integration  community  of 
practice. 
 
                                                
8  On 25 January 2013, SARD and the WCO agreed on six themes for capacity building in South Asian countries: 
(i) general annex provisions of the Revised Kyoto Convention, (ii) the SAFE framework of standards, (iii) authorized 
economic operators, (iv) risk management, (v) post clearance audit, and (vi) time release studies.

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
24.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Trade Facilitation in South Asia, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Under the supervision of the South Asia Department (SARD) team overseeing technical 
assistance  (TA)  implementation,  about  33.5  person-months  of  international  consultancy 
(including resource persons) and 34 person-months of national consultancy will be engaged to 
help  implement  the  TA.  These  consultants  will  report  to  the  designated  international  staff 
member of SARD, who will act as team leader and supervise consultants’ work. Consultants will 
be recruited as individuals in accordance with Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The indicative terms of reference 
for the consultants are set out below. The schedule of recruitment will depend on the results of 
initial consultations that will be conducted at TA inception. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
2.  Trade  facilitation  specialists  (two  positions,  30  person-months  combined).  Trade 
facilitation specialists will have extensive knowledge of transport, trade facilitation, and regional 
cooperation, preferably with at least 10 years of experience working with countries in South 
Asia. Key deliverables will include (i) an interface framework for customs administration systems 
in South Asian Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) countries; (ii) a draft strategy and 
road map for a feasible process of creating better customs administration system interface; and 
(iii) the identification and implementation of priority trade facilitation measures, including regional 
pilot initiatives. Specific tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Help operationalize a customs subgroup in the SASEC trade facilitation and 
transport working group and its biannual meetings.  
(ii)  Facilitate and operationalize experience- and knowledge-sharing workshops and 
seminars on international good practices on customs for South Asian countries.  
(iii)  Draft terms of reference and agendas for customs subgroup biannual meetings 
and knowledge-sharing workshops.  
(iv)  Participate  in  the  activities  of  the  customs  subgroup  and  knowledge-sharing 
workshops.  
(v)  Liaise and work with all resource persons in performing tasks (i) and (ii).  
(vi)  Incorporate  the  outputs  of  all  international  consultants  in  three  related  TA 
projects for Bangladesh, Bhutan, and Nepal regarding the interface framework 
for customs administration systems in SASEC countries and draft a strategy and 
road map for a feasible process of creating an interface.  
(vii)  Identify the benefits of promoting a better interface for customs administration 
systems, determine the associated issues and challenges to be addressed, and 
help  formulate  a  strategy  and  road  map  for  a  feasible  process  of  creating 
customs administration systems interface. 
(viii)  Assess the key barriers to cross-border trade and transport along high-priority, 
high-demand SASEC corridors. 
(ix)  Take stock of existing and planned trade and transport facilitation arrangements 
affecting  high-priority,  high-demand  SASEC  corridors,  including  existing  and 
planned assistance from external development partners. 
(x)  Recommend approaches and measures to facilitate trade and transport along 
high-priority corridors, including formulating detailed and time-bound action plans 
for governments and other stakeholders. 
(xi)  Carry out related tasks as requested by the TA supervising unit specialists.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
3.  Short-term  experts  and  resource  persons  (10  positions,  3.5  person-months 
combined).  The  TA  will  require  highly  specialized  skills  for  evolving  needs,  which  will  be 
addressed by the short-term use of resource persons and experts recognized in their fields and 
possessing good communication skills. The experts may support the work of the international 
trade  facilitation  specialists  and/or  serve  as  trainers  and  resource  persons  in  meetings, 
workshops, and seminars. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
4.  Trade facilitation coordinating analysts (two positions, 34 person-months combined). 
The trade facilitation coordinating analysts will have graduate degrees in economics, business, 
or  related  fields,  as  well  as  experience  in  regional  cooperation.  The  analysts  will  provide 
technical and administrative support for the activities to be implemented. Specific tasks will 
include the following: 
(i)  Help  the  SARD  team  coordinate  TA  activities,  including  facilitating 
communication among the team, the SARD trade facilitation team, consultants, 
and participating governments. 
(ii)  Provide  secretariat  and  coordinating  support  for  all  TA  activities,  including 
administrative and communication tasks at ADB, and organizing and updating TA 
information and data. 
(iii)  Develop and maintain a system to monitor progress in TA implementation. 
(iv)  Prepare progress reports and reference documents for TA meetings, workshops, 
and seminars, as well as for other SARD meetings that include transport and 
trade facilitation on the agenda. 
(v)  Assist the preparation, publication, and dissemination of knowledge products 
coming out of the TA. 
(vi)  Contribute  to  the  SASEC  program  website  information  relevant  to  TA 
implementation. 
(vii)  Organize regional meetings, seminars, and workshops related to the TA. 
(viii)  Carry out related tasks as requested by the TA supervising unit specialists.
